text: this is steven holl una the new york
times I've been covering the tribeca
film festival since its opening now it's
in its ninth year and it is still an
unusual festival that combines a kind of
circus equality with a very serious
filmmaking agenda if there's a trend
this year it is that more and more
movies are hybrids of documentaries and
feature films so that if you didn't know
in advance you were watching a feature
film you might think it was a
documentary this year my favorite movie
that I saw there may be a couple of
others that I didn't is a documentary by
Alex Gibney who did taxi to the dark
side this one is a screen adaptation of
Lawrence Wright's one-man play my trip
to al-qaeda Lawrence Wright was a the
author of the looming tower really great
look about the roots of terrorism in the
Middle East and that's a brilliant
brilliant movie besides alex gibney
there are other directors who have a
major work in the festival Jean Pierre's
you know famous for Emily and for
delicatessen who's Jean run to himself
micmacs his new entry is is high comedy
surreal high comedy with wonderful
gadgets in it and and a kind of David
and Goliath contest between a bunch of
ragtag junk dealers and a weapons
manufacturer Michael Winterbottom is the
killer inside me a remake a very violent
remake of a very violent movie fatty a
keen critically adored director of
head-on and edge of heaven has a movie
of comedy called soul kitchen which is
quite amusing about restaurants and
fraternal farce and Hamburg Germany I
liked to documentaries one about Joan
Rivers and what about Vidal Sassoon joan
rivers documentary really gets you
behind the scenes and sees how much work
it takes to be Joan Rivers and how
driven she is the Vidal Sassoon movie
left me with respect for hairdressers
that I've never had before because it
really he and reinvented hairdressing as
a kind of architecture the white meadows
is the most poetic film in the narrative
competition and allegorical it's about a
man who rose around from island to
island collecting people's tears in a
jar you can see it as pure poetry it's
quite beautiful I particularly liked it
a dog pound really harrowing film about
a youth Correctional Center in Montana
it looks like a documentary it seems
like a doctor Mary but it's a fictional
film the equivalent of dog pound in the

would think was sons of perdition it's
called it you would think it was a
fictional film because it's almost
exactly like the HBO series Big Love
it's about the runaway teenagers from
from a fundamentalist Mormon sect in
Colorado City Arizona as a community
development project tribeca film
festival has certainly proved its value
I'm fan of the tribeca festival for all
its up and down hot and cold good and
bad entries it's filling a very valuable
purpose and it's very good for New York
